comment: Not as impressed as I thought I would be. Was disappointed.
Nutty and sweet, thick and super smooth
Weird nutty Nutella vibe. Not into nutty bourbons.
KBD can't really do wrong, can they.
Haven't had it in awhile, but I remember being very impressed with it for the price.  Will have to give it another try.
This was the first Bourbon I drank, actually.  And I've been hooked ever since.
Similar to Evan Williams but mo fire!
Very interesting, vanilla flavor, very spicy
Has more of a kick to it. Spicy and delicious.
High rye bourbon super full with great spice
Never does me wrong. Great bottle great price.
More briny/salty than expected. I get the caramel but not the vanilla.
It's sweet with vanilla notes and hints of pecan.
Purchased in 2013 in Lexington Kentucky for approximately $30.

Clean. Some sort of cherry flavor. Like a lot.

-Update - purchased a bottle. Didn't enjoy as much.

Truly one of my favorite bourbons.  I am strictly a boubon guy, decided one day to try this; and I have kept a bottle on the shelf ever since.  Sometimes I won't drink it for a while and forget just how much I enjoy this bourbon.  Did that again tonight. It is just a good quality bourbon for a great price.
More spice on finish than what I thought. Enjoyed neat was sweet tasting

Not sure if it was a bad bottle or what but this had no real high quality tasting notes after I spent an hour, bandaged hands from the wax to taste this.  Spend your money on something else, like regular Johnny drum vs this rip
Off
The nose has a weird vitamin-type smell and the taste has some vanilla but with a harsh alcohol bite. Definitely will be a one-time purchase only.

Now this is a real hidden gem in Bourbons!

101 Proof that has little to no heat or burn & is so smooth & sweet with Carmel notes for those special sipping & on the rocks (Ice)!

If you cannot find it then ask for it...worth the search & the price is usually right!
Very smooth not a lot of burn on the back end. Caramel hints but not sweet. Great for the cost
Had it at Williams & Graham and thought it was nice but a bit hot, had to throw a splash of water in there for sure.

If you have ever visited a rickhouse, the nose on this will make you remember. Worthy of big sniffs in a glencairn glass. Taste and mouthfeel don't live up to the nose but it is still pretty nice. A significant upgrade from the green label Johnny Drum, and while I would buy this again, there are better whiskys at this price point, or even below.
Nice nose with a lot of vanilla, light/medium body, and long spicy finish.
Very average budget bourbon.  Nose of carmelled apples and corn.  Spice notes of cinnamon; light oak.  Dry finish.  Appropriately priced in mid $20's.

Man oh man...I found some of this to try at a bar and I'm so glad I had the chance. Now I have to go on the hunt. Fearful because I cannot recall seeing this in the millions of liquor stores that I have walked in to. This is the red fruit and cream of bourbons mixed with the perfect amount of spice. It's like drinking a high end desert. Have to find it...have to buy it...
Definitely get the classic vanilla, caramel, wood notes. Goes down fantastic and so smooth. Just got this for the first time and will definitely be a regular going forward, especially at $30!
This stuff really impressed, sweet nose and finish is long. Dark amber color.

This is probably the best $24 bourbon I ever had. Nose is sweet, taste is sweet and finish is sweet. Look... I was Into sweets when I downed this and liked it the entire way. BUY IT! Good beginner bottle.

It has a flavor and nose like I haven't had before. Neat breathed for 5 mins. After a few sips: big red (cinnamon) and vanilla on the nose. Maybe a little cherry. Spicy yet smooth. Recommended. Really worth it.
Impressed with this bourbon. Vanilla and caramel notes. Long spicy finish.

The nose is fairly muted...mostly vanilla and wood, with a hint of anise and clove.  Palate starts just slightly sweet and smooth before immediately giving you a blast of cinnamon red-hots and lumber.  Not a hint of wood.  Lumber.  If you grew up heating your house with firewood, it's almost the same as the taste you get from inhaling hours of chainsaw dust as you rip through the semi-seasoned pile of lumber in the heat of summer hoping to get through it before the first snow flies.  For anyone else, go to the home store and smell a stack of rough-cut  4"x4" posts.  Maybe lick one to get the full affect.  If you stick around for a few minutes and let the glass breath you might detect a bit of mincemeat and dark cherries hidden beneath the cinnamon, but the finish is all spice and wood.  I had high hopes for this, but at $35/bottle, I'd stick with E.W. Single Barrel or Elijah Craig Small Batch.
I like the initial taste but the finish is too spicy for me.
Love this bottle. You really get the sweet notes upfront.

What a surprise out of this bottle! I absolutely love it. Sweet nose that rolls onto the palate, but not overbearing. At 101 proof it sips very well. No ice needed at all. A perfect sipper and the price is perfect!
Very sweet, caramel, vanilla. Solid price. True bourbon. Tasty
A lot of oak and sweetness up front followed by spice and then green apples on the back of the tongue.
Strong, but smooth. Spicy on the palate. Great Old Fashioned

Big fruit and vanilla.... Apple pie and custard (the good stuff - apple pie busting out with cinnamon and proper french vanilla custard). Slightly harsh top but nicely knocked down with a splash of water. Lovely discovery.

Sweet and awesome.

- tried the next day and was still good but not quite as sweet as I remembered. Could be a good available sipper.
Very good for the price. Needs some water to mellow out the heavy proof and to bring out the vanilla and oak.

Bought at Solo Vino, June 2017
Has a bite; not as sweet as described
Smells of apple and vanilla. Medium length after taste with a medium burn
Johnny Drum (or something like that) - Willette rye heavy bourbon.  Good, smooth, "spicy".  Rocks maybe over diluting it

Nose - Vanilla/cinnamon caramels, light sort of stale peanut brittle, salted peanut shells.
Taste - Spicy cinnamon/vanilla caramel, light black pepper kick, hint of salted peanuts, lightly drying oak, tiny hint of Luxardo cherry sweetness at the end.
Finish - Lingering but muted cinnamon spice, sweet Spanish peanut sweetness that fades fairly quicky that only leaves this dry oaky, light heat.
Score - 81/100
Final Thoughts - If I tasted this blind, I probably would've pegged it as a Beam product due to the peanut "Beam funk." It's a very easy sipping bourbon for the proof for sure, which I guess is a result of the charcoal filtering. The balance of caramel and peanut funk is a bit weird to me in that it works up until the finish where the peanut funk turns to be a bit too much like stale peanuts. This might be something I turn into something like a peanut butter cup old fashioned by using some chocolate bitters in place of Angostura.

Peanut brittle and vanilla on the nose. A bit sharp on the front end, with a very light mouthfeel. Almost seems like cotton candy with a barely there feel. It's not cloying like cotton candy, but it's sweet. Hints of nuts, caramel, and some wood spice. The spiciness lingers, along with some bitter chocolate, bitter walnuts. This is a great pour, and a steal at $30. 3/29/17
The 15-year (!!!). What. A. Nose. Deep caramel, cinnamon, graham cracker. Fantastic nose. Smooth for the proof. A strange herbal element on the palate. Finishes with leather. Palate doesn't follow the nose, unfortunately, but this is going to have fans. 2 out of 5. 5/9/18

I don't know what this tastes like, but it doesn't taste like bourbon. It's bourbon-ish.  I'm wondering if this year's release is vastly different? If Willett is finally using some of their own distillate instead of strictly sourcing? That being said, I really liked it! My ABC Store emailed that they had received some limited items and this one, at $33 was the most affordable, so I bit. Tried neat in a glenncairn, the nose is unique. Dry and Dusty. Musty orange, backed by dried spices and a light note of apple pipe tobacco. There was a mystery note that I couldn't place until I read another recent review that called it cedar. BINGO. Neat it enters with musty orange followed by very dry astringent oak. There is a light sweetness here, but it's in no way the traditional vanilla, caramel or toffee. A long drying finish with the musty citrus lingering. A tick on the hot side reminding you it's 101 proof. A splash had little effect on the nose and added cinnamon and chocolate to the palate, taming the astringency a great deal. Though my Scotch experience is limited, with a splash it reminded me of a good inexpensive blend, ala Monkey Shoulder. The nose on the empty glass smells of cinnamon bark. This pairs very well with a cigar. There is so much going on here, I've waited until I'm about a 1/3 of the way through the bottle to review, just to be sure. This is not one I'd seek out. but I'll definitely pick it up when I see it. Very different.

Heeeeeeeeeere's Johnny! This reasonably priced bourbon is hard to find so when you see it, grab it. Rich caramel on the nose and a fruity burst on the tongue. Maybe apple or pear or peach? Which in all combinations makes it like a liquid gold version of apple pie. How American is that? It should be because Murica=Bourbon. So those blended Johnnys can "Walker" themselves out of the room. I'm drinking to the beat of the DRUM! Ba yum tss!
Nose is super sweet....almost candied apple. Palate is mild spice with caramel. Long buttery finish without much heat.
A bit hotter due to the higher proof, but exceptionally smooth drinking. Not heavily wheated, so don't expect the richer vanilla and buttered toast notes. Bitter orange and herbs.

I had a 50ml tasting of the 15 year and I really really enjoyed it. It was the top bourbon I'd tried to date and for the price outstanding value. A year later I managed to get a bottle and was very excited however this soon turned to disappointed when I tasted it and wondered what had changed. Then I saw they'd dropped the 15 year age statement off. Very poor form. The bottle was exactly the same just missing the 15 annotation. This version is a pale shadow of its dearly departed 15 year brother
Amazingly smooth and reasonably priced Kentucky bourbon.

Hard to find, and sweet, as its charcoal filtered, but otherwise an excellent Willett bourbon. I prefer to the very similar - but higher proof and not charcoal filtered - Noah's Mill (even when its watered down to the same proof), likely as the filtering reducing some of the strange fruity cinnamon and un-bourbon-like taste otherwise found in Noah's Mill.
Good for the price. I wish I could place the flavor I'm getting. Some sort of fruit. It's definitely unique.

$35/fifth
Relatively smooth, slight deep tingly burn. Has a nice cinnamon touch, but can be a bit too reminiscent of the old fireball days in college.
doesnt oxidize the best.  Picks up heavy leather & mild stale taste
Lots of flavors going on here. Needs a bit of ice melt to tame the heat but a nice whiskey!

What a find!
Dandelions, Fuji apples, wet maple tree bark, and a handful of red hots candy. 
This is a perfect bottle for gifting to others, regardless of bourbon experience.

Aroma: Strong alcohol burns nostrils initially. Nutty, dark caramel and molasses. Subtle peaches/apricot. Light butter. Light cherry/cranberry/pomegranate. Alcohol burn persists. After first sip/acclamation, gingerbread becomes quite apparent. Warm gingerbread cake, raisins, butter and powdered sugar. 

Flavor: Rather neutral at first. Vanilla and light caramel. Macadamia nuts, toasted oats, white chocolate. Roasted/carmelized pear. Becomes more elegant and complex as it lingers.

Mouthfeel: Med-light body. Smooth and unabbrassive at first, then “Kentucky hug” sticks to back of cheeks and mid-throat. Definitely warms you up.

Totally changed my mind & now really like it!  The trick is add some water to cut the proof & do NOT add ice.  Totally different but interestingly good from bourbons I am used to.  I taste more spice than fruits but not too spicy & actually a little sweet (vanilla) @ the end.  Slight nice burn in the mouth but no burn down the throat.  It is a FULL, FLAVORFUL bourbon.  If you have tried & didn't like it, I would say "TRY AGAIN".
Pretty smooth for 101. It didn't blow my socks off but enjoyed it especially for the price point.
Heavy caramel on the nose. Peppery taste. Vanilla. Light corn.
A bit harsh for my liking.  Lower pricing $35 at Market District

3 stars. Nose was lighter than the Rowan creek. Woody caramel. Same flavor and didn’t feel like 101proof. Liked it less with water...more alcohol flavor with a few drops. Maybe would buy. Not as good as willet pot still reserve (but Christi liked it more).

Some herbal notes I’m not really into. Strong red hots flavor is kind of interesting. It’s okay but not a favorite. 

3 ⭐️ / $35 / Total Wine / LA
Vanilla and tobacco is the flavor profile I have heard and sweet. I haven’t tried it, but will keep an eye out.

Doesn't taste like a 101 proof bourbon. Lots of sugar, vanilla and oak. Quite liked it. Update: Liked it so much tried it again at Jockey's at the Galt House Hotel in Louisville. Liked it again so when I left KY, I picked up a bottle to come home with me.

No age statement bottle neat; Strong alcohol nose with a touch of vanilla. Sweet oak flavor. Sweet caramel oak finish. Sweet finish off putting sharp finish. Alcohol undertones throughtout.
$34.99 750ml at Total Wine Dallas, TX
Had with a rock last week. Quintessential bourbon, nice vanilla notes, some heat. Will drink again.

Green gold wax top 15 year old 
Bottom of glass reads 132 14 1949 with a 31 in the center
101 proof 50.5%
A bit briney like all of the Willet’s tonight...
Cinnamon on the palate. Hot on the front with loads of cinnamon through the middle. Medium long finish. Makes a pretty interesting component for a julep.

Tasting yet to come.
NASA Liquors - $29.99 (8-14-18)
Boozy. Caramel. Syrup. Sweetness. Very smooth. An enjoyable treat.
101 proof. Burns all the way down. Hard to taste any flavors with this strength
It’s a little something. Need to figure out the flavor I don’t enjoy

Too much cinnamon on the nose and the palate.  Would not have been surprised if this were a flavored whiskey.  Unpleasant alcohol taste.  Tastes ok in a Manhattan.  Would not buy a bottle or a dram, for sipping or mixing, but I wouldn't pour it out if I had a bottle (which I do now).
Little burn, spice on the tongue. Tasting a bit of apple/cinnamon
Very good for the price. Slightly rough if not on the rocks
good, hot. I added a splash of water and wow. delicious
It's a smooth drinker, and has what I can only describe as a classic bourbon profile. Pretty run of the mill for the price point. Try it at a bar before you buy a bottle.

This is a tasty if rather unremarkable pour. Very easy to drink. Nice proof. For around $40 a bottle my biggest gripe is it's lack of complexity. It's pretty sweet, prodominently brown sugar notes. You do get some spice and oak notes on the finish but that's it. It's not bad. I'd buy another pour. But for the bottle price there are better options.
no matter what you want from a bourbon, I feel this hits all the marks. I'm very particular about having specific qualities, but has so much to offer all around, I absolutely love it
Caramel, cherries, cinnamon red hot candies. Pretty long tingling finish
Lacked flavor seemed to be flat nothing going on with it
smooth for 101. proof, no bite or burn, nice
Bit sharp, and not just the proof. Great in nog.

Nose: Corn, vanilla, brown sugar and steamed apples. 
Pallet: Starts dry with rye spice, astringent 
Finish: Buttery vanilla and caramel finish
Probably the worst bourbon I've ever had. It's almost like jack mixed with big red gum
Super good. Smooth with a little kick.

Vanilla and apple on the nose. 

A lot oaky/nutty flavor, almost earthy. 

Pleasant creamy mouthfeel. 

Sits on the middle of the tongue and finishes very smooth.

Very ok. Slightly disappointed. Tastes like a red hot with maybe some cherry influence. I really didn’t get much past that. Even the nose is just a lot of cinnamon. It wasn’t bad, just not as good as I’d hoped.
Cinnamon and not much else. Does not drink to it’s 101 proof. It’s fine, but not something I’d buy again.
Good drinker. Heavy cinnamon with some barrel and vanilla. A little hot, works well with a couple drops of water.
Little bitty, could be smooth taste the alcohol but not awful
STRONG cinnamon on the nose. Relatively smooth given the proof. A little on the sweater side. Probably won’t buy again.
Hot, but could taste the caramel finish. Vanilla on the nose. Good with a ball of ice! Good bottle to keep around for friends
medicinal. and oak on the nose, cinnamon candies with some differnet spice on the pallet, enjoyable long finish

caramel 
toasted almonds
vanilla on the nose
slightly peppery
strong finish

Guy at Spec's recommend. 100 proof and it shows on first sip.  Mellows over ice.  Too young. Only the smallest hint of oakiness. Faint carmel and vanilla. Dissolved 2 small ice cubes in a finger.  Burn taste was mellow. Second taste, no real flavor,  just hints of what bourbon could be.  Nothing at all in 3rd or 4th taste.  Best use is for "bourbon"  cocktails  for people who don't like bourbon cocktails.

Alright since it’s officially become mixed with actually Willett distillate it’s definetly changed profile from its original Aged stated NDP stuff....
This nose is massive peanut funk like almost that Evan Williams peanut funk but more dirty sock vibe (almost like the old Ezra 7yr 101) 
It’s taste is like almost salty and sweet peanut brittle with a gentle finish of sweetness. 
#important note my bottle has been 1/3 full for about two months now so oxidation has greatly effected this...
My recommendation is to let it breathe some as it softened the bitter rough vibes
Solid sour mash bourbon. It’s sweet and has quite a bit of bite from the rye. Good for $30
Immediate cinnamon and very interesting mid to finish profile. Very enjoyable will buy again.
Really complex flavors. Hearty color. Great nose. Smoother than bookers
Slow roll of a slight warmth, gums are hit nicely
Smooth and pleasant. Rich, sweet. Pretty good value and very nice balance for a bourbon
Light. Very good. Ready to drink.

nose has milk chocolate, light coffee, vanilla, oak and cinnamon notes.  
sweet and warm front with cereal grain notes and cacao, but mostly corn. sweet, woody...  warm. some spice on finish.   well balanced.  excellent value.
Nice smoky flavor.  Early burn that gives way to a nice warmth that lasts about 2-3 minutes.
Vanilla and apple pie with a long finish. It has a nice balance of sweet and heat.
Wanted to wait to rate. After 5 pours, it’s still there. Lots of cinnamon & dried fruit. Very little heat. Sweet & Smooth. Way Closer to ORVW than any W 12 I’ve ever tried.

The nose is immediately poached apple with sweet caramel sauce, sugar syrup, mild baking spices and sweet oak. The oak is stronger on the palate and is followed by caramel apple and baking spices for a rich and oily mouthfeel. The finish is medium long with fading oak and baking spices while the caramel apple softly lingers.

750ml neat in Glencairn at home.  $33.99 at Morris Miller Liquors in DC.  Nose has vanilla, rye spice, green apples. Touch of heat.  Nice.  Taste is more sharp, with some grassy notes amongst the spicy rye, some bitterness, along with a hint of apples and caramel.  Lingering spice.  I don't love it, but it is quite decent for the price.  8/5/19.
An outstanding value with a nice combination of sweet and heat at 101 proof. Can’t find McKenna anymore? Time to check out Johnny Drum.

Nose is heavy ethanol. Maybe some faint cinnamon. But overwhelmingly ethanol. However, this is a flavorful bourbon. Didnt get much apple, but caramel and cinnamon with a touch of vanilla. The spice comes on the finish but it's just enough to accentuate the taste. Pretty solid bourbon at this price point once you get past the nose.
Baking pie spices, complex, sweet caramel

Great daily drinker under $30  Nose is like a smoky oaky fire pit , cinnamon, and some sweetness with vanilla.  Not much astringency at all.  Palate coats the mouth nicely, and is similar to the nose but with some spice/heat.  The finish continues the theme and really lingers nicely.  I really like this for the price.  7.9/10
Really appreciating the cinnamon notes tonight
Not bad for the price, proof gives it bite, sweetness to it as well. Me gusta.
Vanilla and oak and I get a distinct cinnamon flavor. Medium finish. Better with food than stand alone. A little astringent by itself.

Stewed apples on the nose along with dried corn stalks. Extremely approachable for a 101 proof. Sweet on the lips even before ingesting. I've heard about this for quite some time and I'm super happy to have tasted this.

This is a hot mess and tastes a lot like the story that leads it... this flavor profile is exactly like a 15 year old kid named Johnny wildly beating a drum. No rhythm and no depth, just marketing of low-grade sourced bourbon.

On the nose a light apple smell followed by a sweet cinnamon smell (Like Big Red Gum)

Taste: Strong Cinnamon taste on the tongue with a burn followed by a very very slight sweet taste again like big red gum.

Some say a few drops of water may open it up, and it certainly does. I prefer drinking it neat. If you like big red gum this is definitely for you!

Not anywhere close to my favorite bourbon, but it's a great dessert whiskey or just everyday drink.  It has a flavor profile full of apple, caramel, vanilla, and spice.  It'd be great with a slice of apple pie and vanilla ice cream.  It's incredibly drinkable straight even at 101 proof - it's hard to believe that it's such high proof.

I think that it'd be great on ice or in certain mixed drinks as well as drinking straight.  It would also be great to share with family during the holidays.

It's a great value at MSRP.

Taste:  Neat in glen cairn, 1.5 oz, then 2 drops water.

Nose (4.25): Fresh roasted peanuts and carmel hit you right away.  it is that smell you get at a baseball game when the beer vendor passes the peanut guy.  I loved it.  Brought back childhood memories.

Palate: (4.25)  Would be 5 if more complex or higher proof.  The nose turns to straight up peanut brittle with a hit of baking spice.  I am all in on this one.

Finish:  (4.25) Vanilla and heathbar at the end.  Just that little bit of chocolate makes me want more.  And then you get some cinnamon at the end.

Overall:  I have found an everyday drinker that rivals the imposters for twice the price.  This is straight up, no frills, traditional bourbon the way it should be.  It succeeds by NOT trying to be what it isn't.  I had trouble trying to find ways to knock it down!  If this were a cask strength.....straight 5!

Interesting. I've had many pours of bourbons over the years, and today I had a whiff of something very different.  I opened the bottle of private stock, and there it was, right in front of my nose, a very distinct smell of cinnamon red hot Tomales. Sweetness of the candy, and spiciness of the cinnamon. 
I hate hot tomales..... let's see.
In the glass, rye, cinnamon, bourbon spice, honey, strong vanilla, and 'drum roll'.......chocolate coated orange peel.
I hate chocolate coated orange peel..... this won't end well.
Tasting, basically the same as nose, with a nice amount of oak. Big barrel involved. Great char mixing with all that great spiciness, and unbelievable sweetness. The rye really shines through on this one. Excellent.
Finish is long, nice and flavorful.
I added a little water to it, and the taste became a chewy caramel chocolate candy. Liked the taste better with water, but the nose gets dulled.
Will be getting again, interested the heck outta me. If you want something different, I would strongly recommend this whiskey. Awesome stuff and at this price, no brainer.
Definitely a strong traditional varnish nose with slight hints of all spice and nutmeg. A little harsh on first taste but goes down really smooth.
Hard deciding between Cubs-Cards, Shark Week, and April Ross tonight.

Charcoal filtered - the first thing that impresses is the drinkability, even at 101 proof. Full and creamy viscosity. Bakes spices, sweet vanilla, toasted oak, and cinnamon apples on the nose. Oak forward on the palate, but all of the flavors from the nose are present in the palate and finish. Long finish with a little heat and tingle, but exactly what you're looking for. I have to say that I'm really impressed with this one at $31.99. It doesn't have the light smoky finish that the Johnny Drum Black has, but I prefer it that way in this one. I tasted this one next to a Weller Reserve, and I'd pick Johnny Drum Private Stock every time. Willet made some delicious juice right here. 92/100.

first try: 
on the nose it had something extra that twinged my nose more than just ethanol burn.  sweet bourbon with a hint of wet dog or dusty corn or cooked apples.  Hard to say.  

on the palate it was
HOT to the point it distracted from other notes.  maybe that was the cinnamon or its unrefined.  idk. even let it sit to mellow but no.  with water,  i finally was able to get to the other notes and get the cooked apples which added a tartness.  this was unlike any other bourbon and that's why i liked it even though it fought me the whole way.   looking forward to trying again and see what ice will do.   this wasn't the longest,  smoothest ride but a rickety wooden coaster that was basic and scared you a little.  

does anyone else do a screw cap under wax? that cap was a pain to crack open.

Second go around. I feel like the body may be a little bit heavier and the legs just a little bit slower in the glass than I noticed before.  

Nose was again a bit dusty and astringent at first but opening up I do feel like I appreciate more cherries and leather.  There may be a little bit of baked apple pie behind it as well.

The palate definitely has some quick sweetness that is washed away with burn and a little toffee.  Two drops of water does something to bring about maple pecan pancakes, but doesn’t do much to change the pallet.

I really wanted to like this one. I have high hopes to find a wheated bourbon that isn’t such a pain in the ass to hunt down. Sadly I don’t think this is the one.
Burn on the tongue and leaves bad after hot feeling in chest

The bottle had a layer of dust and significant force was required to open the twist off top.  Looked over for awhile, I let this one sit for a minute.  The color is a darker Golden with relatively quick legs for the proof.  The initial nose is ethanol but after sitting becomes more of a Apple/pear with slight caramel.  The palate starts with a bit of sour sweetness and evolves with caramel vanilla and slight oak on the end.  The finish is a lasting apple sweetness this being the first opening of the bottle.
Delicious. I had 3. Baking spices and apple with a rich, long finish and a nice Kentucky hug.
Shared by Carrie and Jonathan Craft. A little hot and needed a couple ice cubes to open it up. Solid otherwise.
Earthy probably will not buy again... update it has opened up and I like it more
It has a sizable bite, with a creamy finish! This has become an everyday for me! Great price and awesome flavor.
A good solid bourbon, a lil spicy on the nose, but doesn’t taste that way once in your mouth. Fairly traditional taste and short finish. Pay retail for it and you’ll be pleased

This bourbon has a strong initial smell of ethanol. I also get some wood and vanilla on the nose. Taste has some caramel flavors and hints of smoke and tobacco. Very smooth. Short finish with no burn. Some lingering smoke on the palate. 

Overall I like this for the price and proof. Not too complex, but a nice easy sipper.
Strong flavor profile doesn't seem "watered down", yet smooth. Vanilla/caramel with a surprising easy finish for the proof. Price point is @ $35 and can find it most stores
Vanilla with a harsh finish. Look at use in mixed drinks to combat the finish.

Sourced or otherwise, this has clearly been blended with the Willett flavor profile in mind.  Spicy, cinnamon red-hots dominate this slightly hot blend, although I didn’t get much of the “Apple” notes many others have touted. I do taste enough barrel spice to believe there are some old barrels blended with the young ones that put a hotter, ethanol based spin on the nose and front palate.  It finishes extra warm, spicy, and long. For around $30 this is a bargain
Very good. Best with 1 small ice cube
Recommended by Jim. Butterscotch notes and a solid sipper.

Color: copper

Aroma: crisp apple pie and light oak notes

Taste: saweeeet hit initially and then baking spices and vanilla propagate as it coats the mouth

Finish: surprisingly long and satisfying, creamy and tingly

Smooth factor: B+
Slight vanilla with a cinnamon finish
Carmel, slight sweet smell, slight burn on finish, hint of orange on finish
Vanilla,cinnamon,smooth little sweet not bad for 35 bucks
A good mixer with ginger ale but not one I would drink neat on a regular basis.  Bought on a trip out of my state and on a friends recommendation as a budget bottle.
Ethenal on the nose, I get a caramel sweetness that transitions to a leathery taste rounding out with spice.
If you like "dark" tasting notes such as molasses, Karo syrup, and raisins then you'll love this stuff.
Not a fan. I get a ton of cinnamon almost like fireball. Maybe i got a bad bottle but not worth another try for me.
Similar flavor profile to Willett’s bourbon, but not as intricate. For the price, it’s decent but for a little more, Willett’s regular branded stuff is better.
Heavy apple cinnamon notes, the cinnamon takes over the finish and makes the tounge sizzle for a lengthy time. Almost a family member to fireball without the sugar.
Sweet vanilla with a sharp bite at the back end, dries the throat
Had a flight of five bourbons; this was the first, and the best. Had a husky, grain like palate. Sweet, but not overpoweringly so. Oily texture. Hard to get aroma from this glassware.
Surprisingly smooth and sweet for a high proof bourbon.

Light butter rum, vanilla, pepper and cinnamon on the nose. 
Very aromatic flavor profile with new leather, wet oak and cologne elements. Citrus oil creeps in farther along on the journey.
There’s a reasonable amount of heat on the backend to keep it interesting.

Spicy on the nose for sure. My first thought was paint, actually. Maybe because I had painted a room in my house earlier in the week. Sour apple nose?

Very accurate description by the pro. 

Not my favorite, I tend to lean towards less spicy but still a good dram. Only my first glass so we shall see what the next glass tastes like.

Update...

Second day, second drink. So much better than the first. Not sure why, but it is.  Nice baking spices, smooth with some heat that isn’t overpowering. Nice proof as well.

Bottle is gone. Final conclusion...I liked that bottle. It took some time but I really liked it.  I would buy this again, especially for $35.00
Blech.  Overwhelming grass flavor (which I remember from my days as a little league right fielder).  Overpriced and poor bourbon, too bad!

101 Proof, but light enough to be approachable most any time. I get vanilla and sugar with a hint of smoke, almost like Creme Brulee on the tongue. It finishes smoky and holds on the palate for a surprisingly long time. This is spectacular at the price point. I'm a fan.
Sweet dark fruit on the front and nice oak on the finish. Not always available in my neck of the woods. I like it!

Before the review starts, as long as Willett/KBD continues to put wax on screw top bottles I’m going to continue clowning them for it. :)

Nose is pungent with toffee, candied nuts, prune, date, fig, pear, and maybe I’m hallucinating, but getting a hint of patchouli oil. All this riding on a bed of alcohol fumes underneath. That critique aside, this aroma is my jam.

Palate is bold and opens with rich nutty toffee and molasses notes with some of that fig and pear from the nose in the mid-palate. Quickly transitions to the medium length finish of hot cinnamon gummy bears and peppermint, which then morphs again into a lingering brittle and nut. Nice ride. 

Mouthfeel is unctuous; fatty and oily. Not sure if this is chill filtered or not but it sure doesn’t feel like it. 

I will say, this surprised me a bit even thought I do tend to be a fan of Willet expressions. While it does suffer from a little lack of complexity initially, the richness of the flavors and interesting finish make up for it. Lot more going on than it’s cheaper, inferior, higher proof cousin Pure Kentucky XO, and more rich and decadent than it’s sister Rowan’s Creek. An under the radar bourbon; at $45, “it’s a rebuy for me, dawg”
Cracking bourbon- vanilla and clove on the nose and a great smooth caramel taste. Very easy drinking

Finally opened this bottle after a couple of years in the bunker. Pleasantly surprised overall and the palate is the highlight for me. With a couple drops of water it is an easy and flavorful 101 proof to sip on.
Sweet and cinnamon dominates this one for me. Not horrible but not one I will rush back out to buy again.
